content.text: State what is meant by _centripetal acceleration_
State what happens to the magnitude of the centripetal acceleration of the car as it moves around the loop from X to Y
Explain, if the car remains in contact with the track, why the centripetal acceleration of the car at point Y must be greater than \(9.8 \text{m s}^{-2}\)
An unpowered toy car moves freely along a smooth track that is initially horizontal. The track contains a vertical circular loop around which the car travels, as shown in Fig. 1.1
The mass of the car is \(230\mathrm{g}\) and the diameter of the loop is \(62\mathrm{cm}\). Assume that the resistive forces acting on the car are negligible
The initial speed at which the car in **(b)** moves along the track is \(3.8 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
Determine whether the car is in contact with the track at point Y. Show your working
Suggest, with a reason but without calculation, whether your conclusion in **(c)** would be different for a car of mass \(460 \text{g}\) moving with the same initial speed
State the relationship between gravitational potential and gravitational field strength
Explain why \(\phi\) is negative throughout the entire range \(x = 2R\) to \(x = D - R\)
One of the features of Fig  .........  2.2 is that \(\phi\) is negative throughout
Describe **two** other features of Fig. 2.2
On Fig. 2.3, sketch the variation with \(x\) of the gravitational field strength \(g\) at point P between \(x = 2R\) and \(x = D - R\)
A moon of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) orbits a planet of mass \(3M\) and radius \(2R\). At a particular time, the distance between their centres is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
Point P is a point along the line between the centres of the planet and the moon, at a variable distance \(x\) from the centre of the planet
The variation with \(x\) of the gravitational potential \(\phi\) at point P, for points between the planet and the moon, is shown in Fig. 2.2
State what is meant by an elastic collision
State two other assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases
One of the assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases is that all collisions involving molecules of the gas are elastic
the magnitude of the change in momentum of the molecule on colliding with a face
change in momentum =   .........
the time between consecutive collisions of the molecule with the shaded face
the average force exerted by the molecule on the shaded face
force =
the pressure on the shaded face if the force in **(iii)** is exerted over the whole area of the face
pressure =
A molecule of an ideal gas has mass \(m\) and is contained in a cubic box of side length \(L\). The molecule is moving with velocity \(u\) towards the face of the box that is shaded in Fig. 3.1
The molecule collides elastically with the shaded face and the face opposite to it alternately
Deduce expressions, in terms of \(m\), \(u\) and \(L\), for:

When the model described in **(b)** is extended to three dimensions, and to a gas containing \(N\) molecules, each of mass \(m\), travelling with mean-square speed \(\langle c^2 \rangle\), it can be shown that
where \(p\) is the pressure exerted by the gas and \(V\) is the volume of the gas
Use this expression, together with the equation of state of an ideal gas, to show that the average translational kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by
where \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas and \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant
The mass of a hydrogen molecule is \(3.34 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\)
Use the expression for \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) in **(c)** to determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of a molecule of hydrogen gas at \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Describe the features of the line in Fig. 4.2 that demonstrate that the motion of the trolley is simple harmonic
Use Fig. 4.2 to determine the period \(T\) of the oscillations of the trolley
On the line of the graph of Fig. 4.2, label with the letter P one point where the kinetic energy of the trolley is zero
On the line of the graph of Fig. 4.2, label with the letter Q an approximate position of one point where the kinetic energy of the trolley is equal to the potential energy stored in the springs
A trolley on a smooth surface is attached by springs to fixed blocks as shown in Fig. 4.1

The trolley oscillates horizontally about its equilibrium position with an amplitude of \(12\mathrm{cm}\). Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of the acceleration \(a\) of the trolley with displacement \(x\) from its equilibrium position. Friction between the trolley and the surface can be assumed to be negligible
When audio signals are transmitted over long distances, modulation of radio waves is used
Suggest a reason why modulation is used
State a technical advantage and a technical disadvantage of using frequency modulation rather than amplitude modulation
advantage:
disadvantage:
An audio signal of amplitude \(2.0 \mu \text{V}\) and frequency \(4.2 \text{kHz}\) is to be transmitted using a carrier wave of amplitude \(10.0 \text{mV}\) and frequency \(100 \text{kHz}\)
Either amplitude modulation or frequency modulation may be used
The amplitude modulation is at a rate of \(1 \text{mV} \mu \text{V}^{-1}\)
The frequency modulation is at a rate of \(5 \text{kHz} \mu \text{V}^{-1}\)
Complete Table 5.1 to show the maximum and minimum values of the amplitude and of the frequency of the modulated wave for each type of modulation
For the amplitude modulated wave in (b), determine the bandwidth
bandwidth =   .........  kHz
Define electric potential

An isolated conducting sphere in a vacuum has radius \(r\) and is initially uncharged. It is then charged by friction so that it carries a final charge \(Q\). This charge can be considered to be acting at the centre of the sphere
By considering the electric potential at its surface, show that the capacitance \(C\) of the sphere is given by
where \(\epsilon_0\) is the permittivity of free space
The dome of an electrostatic generator is a spherical conductor of radius \(13 \text{cm}\). It is initially charged so that the electric potential at the surface is \(4.5 \text{kV}\)

A smaller isolated sphere of radius \(5.2 \text{cm}\), initially uncharged, is brought near to the dome. Sparking causes a current between the two spheres until they reach the same potential. Assume that any charge on a sphere may be considered to act as a point charge at its centre
Calculate the charge that is transferred between the two spheres
charge =   .........  C
An operational amplifier (op-amp) has two input terminals and one output terminal
State what is meant by the _gain_ of an op-amp
State two effects of negative feedback on the gain of an amplifier circuit that uses an op-amp
State the name of the type of circuit shown in Fig. 7.1
On Fig. 7.1, label with the letter X a point in the circuit that is considered to be a virtual earth
Calculate the gain of the circuit in Fig. 7.1
Determine the value of \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) when \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) is \(+6.5\mathrm{V}\)
Determine the value of \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) when \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is \(-5.4 \text{V}\)
Fig. 7.1 shows an op-amp circuit that uses negative feedback
On Fig. 8.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the magnetic field at wire Q due to the current in wire P. Label this arrow B
On Fig. 8.1, draw another arrow to show the direction of the force acting on wire Q due to the current in wire P. Label this arrow F
The current in P is \(I\) and the current in Q is \(2I\)
State, with a reason, how the magnitude of the force acting on wire P compares with the magnitude of the force acting on wire Q
State how the direction of the force on wire P compares with the direction of the force on wire Q
Two long straight parallel wires P and Q carry currents into the plane of the paper, as shown in Fig. 8.1
the photoelectric effect
work function energy
State what is meant by:
State the name of the frequency below which no photoelectric current is produced
Explain how the photon model of electromagnetic radiation accounts for this phenomenon
Calculate the work function energy, in eV, of calcium
work function energy =   .........  eV
A polished calcium plate in a vacuum is investigated by illuminating the surface with light
It is found that no photoelectric current is produced when the frequency of the light is less than \(6.93 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\)
State the function of the iron core
Explain why the iron core is laminated
Calculate the maximum value of \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\)
maximum \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}} =\)   .........  V
Calculate the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) current in the load resistor
On Fig. 10.2, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the power \(P\) dissipated in the load resistor for time \(t = 0\) to \(t = 40 \text{ms}\). Assume that \(P = 0\) when \(t = 0\)
The input p.d. \(V_{\mathrm{IN}}\) is a sinusoidal alternating voltage of peak value \(12\mathrm{kV}\) and period \(40\mathrm{ms}\)
Explain, with reference to Fig.10.2, why the mean power in the load resistor is \(70 \text{W}\)
Fig. 10.1 shows a simple laminated iron-cored transformer consisting of a primary coil of 25 000 turns and a secondary coil of 625 turns
The output potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{\mathrm{OUT}}\) is applied to a load resistor of resistance \(640 \Omega\)
A piezoelectric transducer containing a quartz crystal is used to obtain diagnostic information about internal structures
Describe the function of the quartz crystal
Define specific acoustic impedance
Describe, qualitatively, how the specific acoustic impedances of two materials affect the intensity reflection coefficient at a boundary between the materials
_random_
_spontaneous._
Radioactive decay is both random and spontaneous
State what is meant by:
Use Fig. 12.1 to determine the half-life, in minutes, of nuclide X
half-life =   .........  min
At time \(t = 0\), the mass of the atoms of X in the sample is \(5.66 \times 10^{-7} \text{kg}\)
Determine the nucleon number of X
nucleon number =   .........
A sample of radioactive material contains atoms of an unstable nuclide X. The activity of the sample due to the atoms of X is \(A\). The variation with time \(t\) of In \(A\) is shown in Fig. 12.1
